title: 114_hr4929
content: The Act titled "Biennial Commission on Energy Policy Act of 2016" amends the Department of Energy Organization Act by introducing a new section establishing the Biennial Commission on Energy Policy. The "Biennial Commission on Energy Policy Act of 2016" establishes a commission known as the Biennial Commission on Energy Policy, composed of 15 members appointed by various officials within 30 days of the first day. The Biennial Commission on Energy Policy Act of 2016 establishes a commission with 15 members appointed within 30 days of the first session of the 115th Congress. Members serve a 2-year term and appointments aim for diversity in experience. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission members are appointed for a 2-year term and must have professional experience in areas such as governmental service, energy production, renewable energy development, energy law, public administration, fossil fuel production, energy efficiency, environmental policy, labor, workplace safety, commerce and trade, corporate policies, infrastructure, and foreign affairs. No more than 8 members can be affiliated with the same political party. The Commission members must have professional experience in various areas and no more than 8 members can be from the same political party. Government employees cannot serve on the Commission. Members will be compensated and receive travel expenses according to regulations. The Commission, established under subchapter I of chapter 57 of title 5, United States Code, must commence operations within 30 days of all members being appointed. The chairperson and vice chairperson are selected by the members, who can also create subcommittees for specific duties. A quorum of six members is required for meetings called by the chairperson after the initial meeting. The Commission will meet when called by the chairperson or a majority of its members. Quarterly stakeholder meetings will be held to assist the Commission in its duties, with members encouraged to attend either in person or via teleconference. "SEC. 802. Duties and powers of the Commission." The Commission is tasked with analyzing and evaluating various energy sources in the United States, assessing policy options to increase energy supplies and efficiency, and reviewing energy storage and distribution requirements, including intermittent sources. The Commission will analyze stakeholders' roles in creating an integrated energy policy, assess energy programs' effectiveness, make recommendations for executive branch organization changes, and study relevant matters. The Commission will study relevant matters raised at stakeholder meetings and review materials on energy, including laws, regulations, policies, programs, scientific literature, and studies conducted by other entities. Reports on progress are due by July 1. The Commission will submit progress reports to Congress on its activities and information gathered. Additionally, reports with findings, conclusions, and recommendations for actions will be made public via a website. The Commission has the power to hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, administer oaths, create subcommittees with similar powers, accept gifts, and use postal services. The Commission has the authority to contract with government and private agencies, obtain official data from federal departments and agencies, and receive necessary information to carry out its duties. SEC. 803. PERSONNEL MATTERS. The chairperson of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and up to five staff members without following the usual appointment procedures. The compensation for these positions can be determined by the chairperson without adhering to standard pay regulations, with a salary limit set at the level V of the Executive Schedule. Additionally, government employees can be detailed to assist the Commission upon request. The chairperson of the Commission can detail personnel from federal agencies to assist in its duties. The chairperson can also procure temporary services at specified rates. Authorization of $3,000,000 for the Secretary of Energy without fiscal year limitation. Table of contents amendments for sections 801, 802, and 803. Effective date for amendments is the first day of the second session of the 115th Congress.
